message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A survey on LLM-based multi-agent systems: workflow, infrastructure, and challenges
Paper Abstract: Abstract The pursuit of more intelligent and credible autonomous systems, akin to human society, has been a long-standing endeavor for humans. Leveraging the exceptional reasoning and planning capabilities of large language models (LLMs), LLM-based agents have been proposed and have achieved remarkable success across a wide array of tasks. Notably, LLM-based multi-agent systems (MAS) are considered a promising pathway towards realizing general artificial intelligence that is equivalent to or surpasses human-level intelligence. In this paper, we present a comprehensive survey of these studies, offering a systematic review of LLM-based MAS. Adhering to the workflow of LLM-based multi-agent systems, we synthesize a general structure encompassing five key components: profile, perception, self-action, mutual interaction, and evolution. This unified framework encapsulates much of the previous work in the field. Furthermore, we illuminate the extensive applications of LLM-based MAS in two principal areas: problem-solving and world simulation. Finally, we discuss in detail several contemporary challenges and provide insights into potential future directions in this domain.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Multi-agent systems":

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Important characteristics of agents in a multi-agent system include autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).(no content)While multi-agent systems research typically refers to software agents, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Applications and Developments

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Related Research

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

Here are the search results for "Problem solving":

## Overview

Problem solving is the process of achieving a goal by overcoming obstacles, a frequent part of most activities.(no content)Problem solving in psychology refers to the process of finding solutions to problems encountered in life.

## Types of Problems

Problems can be categorized in different ways:

- Simple problem solving (SPS) addresses one issue, whereas complex problem solving (CPS) involves multiple interrelated obstacles.

- Well-defined problems have specific obstacles and goals, while ill-defined problems are troublesome but lack clarity about what resolution to aim for.

## The Problem-Solving Process

The process starts with problem finding and problem shaping, in which the problem is discovered and simplified. The next step is to generate possible solutions and evaluate them. Finally a solution is selected to be implemented and verified.

## Mental Obstacles

Mental obstacles that prevent people from finding solutions include confirmation bias, mental set, and functional fixedness.

## Professional Applications

Professionals such as lawyers, doctors, programmers, and consultants are largely problem solvers for issues that require technical skills and knowledge beyond general competence.

The search results contain information about various problem-solving methodologies, educational programs, and computational approaches to problem solving across different disciplines.

Web search results for query: "Autonomous systems"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous system (Internet) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(Internet)"},{"title":"Wallenberg AI, Autonomous Systems and Software Program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallenberg_AI,_Autonomous_Systems_and_Software_Program"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous system (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Autonomous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system"},{"title":"List of driverless train systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_driverless_train_systems"},{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous decentralized system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_decentralized_system"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"}]

Here are the search results for "Autonomous systems":

The term "autonomous systems" can refer to several different concepts depending on the context:

1. **Internet Autonomous Systems (AS)**: An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.(no content)As of 2025, there are roughly 120,000 allocated ASNs.

2. **Mathematical Autonomous Systems**: In mathematics, an autonomous system or autonomous differential equation is a system of ordinary differential equations which does not explicitly depend on the independent variable.

3. **Autonomous Agents**: An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)An autonomous agent is a system situated within and a part of an environment that senses that environment and acts on it, over time, in pursuit of its own agenda and so as to effect what it senses in the future.

4. **Autonomous Robots**: The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation. Systems such as Motivity can rely on different sensors in different areas, depending upon which provides the most reliable data at the time, and can re-map a building autonomously.

5. **Autonomous Decentralized Systems**: An autonomous decentralized system (or ADS) is a decentralized system composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system. A unique feature of the ADS is that there is no central operating system or coordinator.

Web search results for query: "Artificial Intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Artificial Intelligence:

## Definition and Goals

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

## History and Development

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.(no content)AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## Current Applications and Impact

Artificial intelligence has been used in applications throughout industry and academia. Recent developments include generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI), a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

## Future Goals

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

The field continues to evolve rapidly with both promising applications and important considerations regarding ethics, transparency, and responsible development.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Artificial Intelligence:

## Definition and Goals

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

## History and Development

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.(no content)AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## Current Applications and Impact

Artificial intelligence has been used in applications throughout industry and academia. Recent developments include generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI), a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

## Future Goals

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

The field continues to evolve rapidly with both promising applications and important considerations regarding ethics, transparency, and responsible development.

Web search results for query: "Workflow"

Links: [{"title":"Workflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workflow"},{"title":"Workflow management system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workflow_management_system"},{"title":"Workflow engine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workflow_engine"},{"title":"Workflow application - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workflow_application"},{"title":"Windows Workflow Foundation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Workflow_Foundation"},{"title":"Workflow pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workflow_pattern"},{"title":"Scientific workflow system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_workflow_system"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Wiki workflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wiki_workflow"},{"title":"Workflowy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workflowy"},{"title":"Workflow technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workflow_technology"}]

Here are the search results for "Workflow":

## Definition

Workflow is a generic term for orchestrated and repeatable patterns of activity, enabled by the systematic organization of resources into processes that transform materials, provide services, or process information.(no content)It can be depicted as a sequence of operations, the work of a person or group, the work of an organization of staff, or one or more simple or complex mechanisms.

## Workflow Management Systems

A workflow management system (WfMS) is a software system for setting up, performing, and monitoring a defined sequence of processes and tasks, with the broad goals of increasing productivity, reducing costs, becoming moreagile, and improving information exchange within an organization.

## Workflow Engines

A workflow engine is a software application that manages business processes and is a key component in workflow technology.(no content)A workflow engine manages and monitors the state of activities in a workflow and determines which new activity to transition to according to defined processes.

## Related Concepts

A workflow pattern is a specialized form of design pattern and refers specifically to recurrent problems and proven solutions related to the development of workflow applications and process-oriented applications.(no content)A scientific workflow system is a specialized form of a workflow management system designed specifically to compose and execute a series of computational or data manipulation steps in a scientific application.

Web search results for query: "Reasoning artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Logic for Programming, Artificial Intelligence and Reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_for_Programming,_Artificial_Intelligence_and_Reasoning"},{"title":"Reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reasoning_system"},{"title":"Automated reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_reasoning"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Knowledge representation and reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_representation_and_reasoning"},{"title":"Symbolic artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolic_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Commonsense reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonsense_reasoning"},{"title":"Commonsense knowledge (artificial intelligence) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonsense_knowledge_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Procedural reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Procedural_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Knowledge-based systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge-based_systems"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of reasoning in artificial intelligence:

## What is Reasoning in AI?

The study of automated reasoning helps produce computer programs that allow computers to reason completely, or nearly completely, automatically.(no content)Although automated reasoning is considered a sub-field of artificial intelligence, it also has connections with theoretical computer science and philosophy.

## Key Types of Reasoning Systems

In information technology a reasoning system is a software system that generates conclusions from available knowledge using logical techniques such as deduction and induction. Several approaches are used:

- **Automated Theorem Proving**: The most developed subareas of automated reasoning are automated theorem proving (and the less automated but more pragmatic subfield of interactive theorem proving) and automated proof checking (viewed as guaranteed correct reasoning under fixed assumptions).

- **Expert Systems**: The first practical application of automated reasoning were expert systems. Expert systems focused on much more well defined domains than general problem solving such as medical diagnosis or analyzing faults in an aircraft.

- **Knowledge-Based Systems**: A knowledge-based system (KBS) is a computer program that reasons and uses a knowledge base to solve complex problems.

## Historical Development

The first reasoning systems were theorem provers, systems that represent axioms and statements in First Order Logic and then use rules of logic such as modus ponens to infer new statements.

## Reasoning in AI Goals

The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

Web search results for query: "Planning artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Graphplan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphplan"},{"title":"State-space planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_space_planning"},{"title":"Action selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_selection"},{"title":"Planning Domain Definition Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planning_Domain_Definition_Language"},{"title":"Rainier Mallol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainier_Mallol"},{"title":"Network planning and design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_planning_and_design"},{"title":"Noah Raford - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noah_Raford"},{"title":"Yi Zeng (AI researcher) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yi_Zeng_(AI_researcher)"},{"title":"Raja Chatila - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raja_Chatila"}]

Here are the search results for "Planning artificial intelligence":

## Overview

Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

## Key Concepts and Approaches

**Classical Planning:** Early in the history of artificial intelligence, it was assumed that the best way for an agent to choose what to do next would be to compute a probably optimal plan, and then execute that plan. Many software agents still use this approach for action selection.

**Action Selection Methods:** Artificial action selection mechanisms can be divided into several categories: symbol-based systems sometimes known as classical planning, distributed solutions, and reactive or dynamic planning.

## Planning Algorithms and Languages

**Graphplan:** Graphplan is an algorithm for automated planning developed by Avrim Blum and Merrick Furst in 1995. Graphplan takes as input a planning problem expressed in STRIPS and produces, if one is possible, a sequence of operations for reaching a goal state.

**PDDL (Planning Domain Definition Language):** The Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL) is an attempt to standardize Artificial Intelligence (AI) planning languages. It was first developed by Drew McDermott and his colleagues in 1998 mainly to make the 1998/2000 International Planning Competition (IPC) possible, and then evolved with each competition.

These results cover the fundamental concepts of AI planning, various approaches to action selection, and important algorithms and standardized languages used in the field.

Links: [{"title":"Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Graphplan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphplan"},{"title":"State-space planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_space_planning"},{"title":"Action selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_selection"},{"title":"Planning Domain Definition Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planning_Domain_Definition_Language"},{"title":"Rainier Mallol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainier_Mallol"},{"title":"Network planning and design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_planning_and_design"},{"title":"Noah Raford - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noah_Raford"},{"title":"Yi Zeng (AI researcher) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yi_Zeng_(AI_researcher)"},{"title":"Raja Chatila - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raja_Chatila"}]

Here are the search results for "Planning artificial intelligence":

## Overview

Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

## Key Concepts and Approaches

**Classical Planning:** Early in the history of artificial intelligence, it was assumed that the best way for an agent to choose what to do next would be to compute a probably optimal plan, and then execute that plan. Many software agents still use this approach for action selection.

**Action Selection Methods:** Artificial action selection mechanisms can be divided into several categories: symbol-based systems sometimes known as classical planning, distributed solutions, and reactive or dynamic planning.

## Planning Algorithms and Languages

**Graphplan:** Graphplan is an algorithm for automated planning developed by Avrim Blum and Merrick Furst in 1995. Graphplan takes as input a planning problem expressed in STRIPS and produces, if one is possible, a sequence of operations for reaching a goal state.

**PDDL (Planning Domain Definition Language):** The Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL) is an attempt to standardize Artificial Intelligence (AI) planning languages. It was first developed by Drew McDermott and his colleagues in 1998 mainly to make the 1998/2000 International Planning Competition (IPC) possible, and then evolved with each competition.

These results cover the fundamental concepts of AI planning, various approaches to action selection, and important algorithms and standardized languages used in the field.

Links: [{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Large_language_models"},{"title":"List of large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_large_language_models"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Large language models and copyright - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Large_language_models_and_copyright"},{"title":"Reasoning model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reasoning_language_model"},{"title":"LLM (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LLM_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"1.58-bit large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1.58-bit_large_language_model"},{"title":"Retrieval-augmented generation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retrieval-augmented_generation"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models/Archive 5 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models/Archive_5"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language model policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_model_policy"}]

Here are the key findings from the web search about Large Language Models (LLMs):

## Definition

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Capabilities and Characteristics

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.(no content)LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.

## Training and Parameters

Substantial infrastructure is necessary for training the largest models. For example, the training of GPT-2 (a 1.5-billion-parameters model) in 2019 cost $50,000, while training of the PaLM (a 540-billion-parameters model) in 2022 cost $8 million, and Megatron-Turing NLG 530B (in 2021) cost around $11 million.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes.

Links: [{"title":"Simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation"},{"title":"Discrete-event simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete-event_simulation"},{"title":"Large eddy simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_eddy_simulation"},{"title":"Simulation hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation_hypothesis"},{"title":"Construction and management simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construction_and_management_simulation"},{"title":"Life simulation game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_simulation_game"},{"title":"List of simulation video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_simulation_video_games"},{"title":"Simulation video game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation_video_game"},{"title":"Modeling and simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modeling_and_simulation"},{"title":"Business simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_simulation"}]

I've completed the web search for "Simulation." Here are the key findings:

## General Definition

A simulation is an imitative representation of a process or system that could exist in the real world.(no content)Simulation is used in many contexts, such as simulation of technology for performance tuning or optimizing, safety engineering, testing, training, education, and video games.

## Types of Simulation

**Discrete-Event Simulation**: A discrete-event simulation (DES) models the operation of a system as a sequence of events in time.

**Large Eddy Simulation**: Large eddy simulation (LES) is a mathematical model for turbulence used in computational fluid dynamics.

**Video Game Simulations**: A simulation game attempts to copy various activities from real life in the form of a game for various purposes such as training, analysis, prediction, or entertainment. This includes construction and management simulations, life simulation games, and sports simulations.

## Applications and Benefits

Simulation is also used when the real system cannot be engaged, because it may not be accessible, or it may be dangerous or unacceptable to engage, or it is being designed but not yet built.(no content)Using simulations is generally cheaper, safer and sometimes more ethical than conducting real-world experiments.

## Philosophical Concept

The simulation hypothesis proposes that what one experiences as the real world is actually a simulated reality, such as a computer simulation in which humans are constructs.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper on LLM-based multi-agent systems. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Survey

The paper is a comprehensive survey that systematically reviews existing research on LLM-based multi-agent systems (MAS), synthesizing previous work rather than proposing entirely novel methods.

**Extracted Triples (9 total):**

1. **Large language model** - artifact - uses
   - LLMs are the core technology enabling these multi-agent systems

2. **Multi-agent system** - concept - uses
   - The primary focus of the survey

3. **Autonomous system** - concept - uses
   - Conceptual foundation for independent agents

4. **Automated reasoning** - method - uses
   - Underlies agent reasoning capabilities

5. **Automated planning and scheduling** - method - uses
   - Enables agent planning capabilities

6. **Artificial intelligence** - concept - uses
   - The foundational field encompassing all aspects

7. **Problem solving** - task - uses
   - One of two principal application areas

8. **Simulation** - task - uses
   - The second principal application area (world simulation)

9. **Workflow** - concept - uses
   - The organizational framework for system components

**Validation:** All checks passed successfully ✓

The JSON file has been updated at `./triples_output.json` with complete Wikipedia references for each entity.

Sources:
- [Large language model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Autonomous system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system)
- [Automated reasoning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_reasoning)
- [Automated planning and scheduling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling)
- [Artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence)
- [Problem solving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Problem_solving)
- [Simulation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation)
- [Workflow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workflow)
